G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 1.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 1, as the Plaintiff claims damages arising from violations of Massachusetts law.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1, because the rental property at issue is located in Brockton, Plymouth County, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, every residential tenant in Massachusetts is entitled to the covenant of quiet enjoyment, ensuring that the landlord will not interfere with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the property.

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 283 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Massachusetts law provides that a landlord’s failure to maintain a habitable rental unit, including the provision of essential services such as hot water, constitutes a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The case discusses the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, but in the context of drug-related criminal activity in common areas and the landlord’s failure to take measures to remove nontenants. It does not address habitability issues like lack of hot water or other essential physical services, and it explicitly cabins the warranty of habitability to physical defects. The opinion therefore cannot be cited as authority that failure to maintain a habitable unit or provide essential services such as hot water constitutes a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … [A] landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’ … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (198.proposition: Defendant’s failure to ensure the prompt repair of the hot water system constitutes a breach of G.L. c. 186, § 14, as it seriously interfered with Plaintiff’s ability to use and enjoy the premises.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 broadly and applies it to a landlord’s failure to maintain sanitary, watertight conditions, but the factual and legal basis is repeated sewage flooding, not a failure to promptly repair a hot water system. The court’s discussion of § 14 focuses on interference with quiet enjoyment through unsanitary flooding, not on failure to supply or repair hot water, so using this case as authority for the specific hot-water proposition mischaracterizes its holding.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (198.relevant_excerpt: “Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.” (385 Mass. at 104).

Hemingway v. James, 430 Mass. 112, 118 (.proposition: The Massachusetts courts have consistently held that essential services such as hot water are integral to the habitability of residential premises and cannot be absent for an unreasonable period without violating tenants’ rights.

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 199 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: Defendant’s failure to timely restore hot water after repeated notices amounts to a “constructive eviction” in violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: This concurring/dissenting opinion discusses implied warranty of habitability, the impact of sanitary code violations on rent obligations, and mentions constructive eviction only in passing. It explicitly notes that the suggested rule does not cover constructive eviction and that the present facts do not involve such a situation. It neither interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 nor holds that a failure to restore hot water after notice constitutes constructive eviction, so it does not support the specific proposition cited.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “Admittedly the rule suggested above does not cover the situation constituting a ‘constructive eviction’ of a tenant which is discussed in the court’s opinion, but that is because the facts of the present cases do not involve such a situation. There is nothing to suggest that our courts which have heretofore given relief to a tenant who is the victim of a ‘constructive eviction’ will not continue to do so in an appropriate case.”

Cruz Management Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass..raw_text: Cruz Management Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 789 (1994)
Cruz Management Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass..proposition: Such breaches render Defendant liable for actual damages suffered by the Plaintiff, including but not limited to the direct economic costs of alternative arrangements and the stress, inconvenience, and indignity caused by the deprivation.
Cruz Management Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion discusses remedies for breach of the implied warranty of habitability, breach of quiet enjoyment, and Chapter 93A, but it does not state that the landlord is liable for the tenant’s stress, inconvenience, or indignity, nor does it describe those as recoverable elements of damages. The court focuses on rent-based damages and statutory remedies (including attorney’s fees and potential multiple damages), and explicitly notes that Thomas is not entitled to additional actual damages under G.L. c. 186, § 14, or c. 93A. The specific proposition about ‘stress, inconvenience, and indignity’ as compensable actual damages is not supported by this case.
Cruz Management Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass..relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 186, § 14 (1992 ed.), provides, in pertinent part, that “any lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant . . . shall ... be liable for actual and consequential damages or three month’s rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.” ... Thomas is not entitled to an additional recovery of actual damages on this basis. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 109-111 (1982).
